title: Information about Gothic Extended
content:
Hello,   
   
In a book called 'ABZ More alphabets and other signs' I found this nice grotesk and used it as a base for my typefamily Capone (you can see it at [http://www.caketype.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516054717/http:/www.caketype.com/)). Can anybody tell me more about this typedesign? Thanks. ![Capone base](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516054717im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/68994.gif)
author: Pieter van Rosmalen

comments.content:
That exact specimen is also in Rob Roy Kelly's "American Wood Type: 1828-1900" first published in 1969. The caption (not included in the ABZ book) reads:   
   
"Gothic Extended. This particular cutting made by the Hamilton Company after 1900. Lowercase is missing."   
   
Wood type Gothics like this go back to the 1840s or earlier.

Oh, and, ' [Rhode](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516054717/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Rhode)', by David Berlow, may be another nice and rather close digitisation..   
_( Other 'remakes' may be ' [Brazos](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516054717/http:/www.nicksfonts.com/fonts/brazoswb.html)', by Nick Curtis; and ' [Wooddale](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516054717/http:/www.testpilotcollective.com/paypal/wooddale.html)', by Matt Desmond.. )_

Thanks all!   
Stephen it's a very nice book. Some very nice modular typefaces also.   
Mark thanks for the information. It's good to hear it's cut after 1900 because I named my version after Al Capone. So the period was right.   
Dav thanks for the other interpretations based on the same typeface. I think Rhode isn't based on the same typefase but it's very nice.   
Thanks all!

It is a nice book, but having all the references at the back of the book is such a pain. I was looking at the same font last night I believe it said it was produced in 1837 (it was late, so I might be mistaken) apart from the S and ampersand it is quite attractive.   
Tim
